post.title: Discrete Math

dl.dt: If two tasks can be performed in $m$ and $n$ ways, respectively, then there are $m+n$ ways of doing either.
dl.dd: If two sequential tasks can be performed in $m$ and $n$ ways, respectively, there are $m \times n$ ways of performing the sequence.

post.p:
Given $n$ objects, any linear arrangement of these is a permutation. With permutations order matters and repetitions are not allowed.
The number of permutations of size $r$ a set of $n$ objects is $P(n,r) = \frac{n!}{(n-r)!}$.
Given $n$ objects, with $n_1$ objects of type 1, $n_2$ objects of type 2, etc. where $n_1 + ... + n_r = n$, the number of permutations with repetitions is $PR(n) = \frac{n!}{n_1!n_2!...n_r!}$.
Given $n$ objects, the number of subsets (Combinations) of size $r$ is $C(n,r) = \frac{P(n,r)}{r!}$. Combinations don't preserve order.
The coefficient of $x_1^{n_1}...x_t^{n_t}$ in $(x_1 + ... + x_t)^n$ is $\frac{n!}{n_1!n_2!...n_t!}$.

$CR(n,r) = C(n+r-1, r)$.
The number of combinations with repetitions of $n$ objects in sets of size $r$ is the same as:
The number of integer solutions to the equation $x_1 + ... + x_n = r, x_i \gt 0$.
The number of ways to distribute $r$ identical objects in $n$ distinct containers.
